title: Salvadoran Gang Member Arrested In Arlington For Capital Murder In Dallas
summary:
DALLAS (CBSDFW.COM) – Officers with U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement’s Enforcement and Removal Operations arrested a Salvadoran man in Arlington who was wanted for capital murder.
A Dallas County magistrate judge issued an arrest warrant for Gonzalez-Rosales April 1, 2020, for capital murder.
The following day, ERO San Antonio issued Gonzalez-Rosales a Notice to Appear, and on Feb. 7, 2018, an immigration judge grant him bond.
Gonzalez-Rosales did not appear for his July 16, 2018, immigration court hearing, and an immigration judge in San Antonio ordered him removed in absentia to El Salvador.
Gonzalez-Rosales who will remain in ICE custody until he is transferred to the Dallas County Jail to face the pending capital murder charges.

summary:
(May 19, 1926 – April 13, 2020)Glenda Hitt McKinzie, age 93, passed away on Monday, April 13, 2020, in Comanche, Texas.
On June 11, 1944, she was united in marriage to Loyd Hitt in Comanche.
She married Theron McKinzie in Comanche on August 8, 1975.
Glenda was a devoted wife, mother, grandmother, great-grandmother and great-great-grandmother.
She is survived by her daughter, Sara Hitt Williams of Comanche; sons: Roger Hitt and wife Lou of Decatur, Wayne Hitt and wife Leslie of Granbury, and Roy Hitt and wife Sandy of Arlington; eight grandchildren: Lewis Williams, Lesle Williams McGuffey, Nick Hitt, Michael Bradshaw, Shelly Hitt Laaser, Nathan Bradshaw, Jessi Hitt and Rachel Hitt; eleven great-grandchildren, and one great-great-granddaughter.

title: Coronavirus: Rob Manfred, MLB senior staff’s salaries to be ‘reduced an average of 35%,’ league to pay employees until at least May 31 (report)
summary:
MLB commissioner Rob Manfred sent a memo to league staff members Tuesday stating he will pay them through at least May 31 while the senior members of the staff will take pay cuts, ESPN’s Jeff Passan reported.
Manfred and other senior staff members will see their salaries reduced by an average of 35%, per Passan.
MLB suspended its seasons indefinitely in March because of the coronavirus outbreak.
Manfred said on Fox Business on Tuesday the league has discussed “various contingency plans” but baseball returning is based on the improvement of public health.

title: Motorcyclist killed in collision with SUV in Arlington
summary:
A motorcyclist was killed after colliding with an SUV in Arlington Thursday evening, police say.
The incident took place at 6:02 p.m. in the 1200 block of South Bowen, where police believe the motorcycle had just passed Park Row Drive headed northbound when it hit the SUV, which had just exited a private business in the area.
The motorcyclist was ejected from the bike and pronounced dead at the scene.
No identity was available, pending notification of relatives.
Two people in the SUV were uninjured, police said, and the crash remains under investigation.

title: GM Arlington to move nearly 300 temporary workers to full-time
summary:
Close to 300 temporary workers at General Motors’ Arlington assembly plant are being moved up to full-time status, the automaker announced Wednesday.
Nationwide, more than 1,350 hourly GM employees at 14 manufacturing plants and other sites in eight states will be elevated to full-time status.
The Arlington assembly plant is a critical manufacturing site for GM, which builds its popular Chevrolet Tahoes, Suburbans, GMC Yukon, Yukon XLs and Cadillac Escalades there.
The additional workers in North Texas are a result of a June announcement of a $20 million investment in the Arlington plant.
The workers got a path to full-time status in contract negotiations between the UAW and company.

"Globe Life Field gives us the option to have earlier start times on weekends," said Rangers Executive Vice President for Business Operations Rob Matwick.

title: Teen Girl Killed in Outbreak of Shootings in Fort Worth
summary:
A 17-year-old high school student from Arlington who dreamed of being a nurse was shot and killed in a violent weekend in Fort Worth.
She was shot in the 5700 block of East Rosedale Sunday evening and later died at John Peter Smith Hospital, police said.
The victim was transported to the hospital with injuries that police said were serious but not life-threatening.
Minutes later, police also responded to a shooting at a house in the 7800 block of Novella Drive in South Fort Worth.
Police don't believe the rash of shootings were related but have made no arrests so far, Fort Worth police spokesman Officer Tracy Carter said.

title: Six Flags will relocate headquarters to Globe Life Park’s centerfield office by summer
summary:
Six Flags Entertainment Corp. has finalized an agreement to move its world headquarters to the old home of its longtime Arlington neighbor, the Texas Rangers.
The theme park operator signed a 15-year lease to occupy the Centerfield Office Building at Globe Life Park in Arlington.
“Six Flags and the Texas Rangers share a long history as the original venues that made up the Arlington Entertainment District.
Conveniently located next to its Six Flags Over Texas theme park, the offices will house 120 full-time employees, according to the company.
Six Flags is the world’s largest regional theme park operator, employing more than 50,000 people at 26 parks worldwide.

title: Pregnant Woman, Unborn Child And Driver Killed In Arlington Wrong-Way Crash
summary:
ARLINGTON, Texas (CBSDFW.COM) – A pregnant woman and her unborn child were killed after being struck by a car going the wrong way on Matlock Road near I-20 in South Arlington Thursday night.
The mother of the pregnant woman was seriously injured and remains hospitalized.
Family members confirm the wrong-way driver, who was also killed, was 27-year-old Tristan Bustillos.
“We don’t know if there was a medical condition, some kind of impairment, a distraction,” said Arlington Police Lt. Christopher Cook.
Police have not released the name of the pregnant woman who was killed, but her mother’s condition is said to be showing some improvement.

title: How should college students fill out the census?
summary:
AUSTIN ― Even under normal circumstances, college students often don’t know they need to count themselves in the U.S. census or don’t know where they should be counted.
Now, with the coronavirus outbreak, the U.S. Census Bureau has paused its field operations, and there are fears that more confusion could arise among college students.
A hard to count demographicIt’s hard to count college students because they may not consider their college town or temporary living arrangement their home, said Bianca Gámez, senior media specialist with the Dallas Regional Census Center Field Division.
“Especially those that move away to go to college, they're living in another area in another city or in another community, so it's important for college students to complete the census,” she said.
For students living in college dorms or sorority or fraternity housing, a representative for the living quarters can usually submit a listing of all students so students can respond online, choose to have census questionnaires be dropped off and picked up, or have a census taker interview them in person.

summary:

title: 1 Dead After Single Vehicle Crash in Arlington
summary:

According to the Arlington Police Department, officers responded to a crash involving a single vehicle with a lone occupant in the 1900 block of East Arkansas Lane at about 2:25 a.m.Investigators believe the vehicle was traveling eastbound on Arkansas Lane when it crossed over the median, hitting a light pole and a tree.
Police say the vehicle also collided with a utility line and caused gas leak.
Arkansas Lane was shut down between New York Avenue and Sherry Street as officers responded to the incident.
Police are still investigating the causes of the crash, but officers believe that the driver may have lost control of his vehicle because he was traveling at a high rate of speed.

title: Cooper Webb Injury Update Arlington Supercross
summary:
As he went sailing off the track upside down in a devastating flip, heading right toward the concrete surrounding the track, it appeared the Monster Energy Supercross title defense was over for Cooper Webb.
At round eight of the championship in Arlington, Texas, Webb endoed off of a dragon's back during the second race of the Arlington Triple Crown, rode the front wheel into the face of the next triple, and was then catapulted over the bars, landing flat on his back on the concrete floor.
It was a brutal hit.
The crash took Webb out of competition for the night (he had finished second in the first race of the Triple Crown) and he ended up scoring 12th overall with 2-17-20 scores.
But while those scores were being calculated, he was also taking a trip to the hospital.

Schecter donated a kidney to Nate Jones, a father to three students attending the school.

title: Public Input Sought On Arlington's 2020-2024 HUD Consolidated Plan
summary:
From the City of Arlington:February 20, 2020Public Input Sought on Arlington's 2020-2024 HUD Consolidated Plan and 2020 Annual Action PlanBy Office of CommunicationPosted on Thursday, February 20, 2020The City of Arlington will hold a series of three public hearings to receive public comments regarding general needs and priorities for the 2020-2024 HUD Consolidated Plan and Annual Action Plan for Community Development Block Grant (CDBG), HOME Investment Partnerships, and Emergency Solutions Grant (ESG) programs.
The 2020-2024 HUD Consolidated Plan and Annual Action Plan for the City of Arlington are designed to identify housing and community development needs in the City and to establish goals, priorities, and strategies to address those needs, especially for low- and moderate-income households.
These public hearing are part of a communitywide dialogue designed to obtain input which will focus funding from the U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development (HUD) grant programs to meet local needs.
For questions about the 2020-2024 Consolidated Plan, the Annual Action Plan, or to request accommodations or interpretive services, please contact 817-459-6258 at least 48 hours before the meeting.

title: NANCY M. CARTER
summary:
Nancy Marie Pettett Carter, 80 of Magnolia passed away in peace Wednesday, March 18 at Baylor Hospital in Dallas, Texas.
Nancy Marie was born December 2, 1939 in Port Angeles, Washington to Gene Pettett and Dorothy (Basteyns) Pettett.
Nancy began her long career as a social worker in the 1980s after completing a Bachelor of Psychology and a Master of Social Work at the University of Texas at Arlington.
Nancy’s real love began when she left agency work and began a 30-year private practice as a therapist.
She is survived by her sister-in-law Dolores Schwerdfeger and her extended family, her children and their spouses Brian Carter (Delores), Laura Johnson (Tom), her grandchildren and their spouses Nicole Ayers (Jeremy), Bryan Carter (Sarah), Stephen Carter, Claire Carter, Grace Carter, Candy Johnson, Shawn Johnson (Sarah), her sister-in-law Li Pettett, four nieces and two nephews, five great-granchildren, and more.

title: Wanda E. Kimble, Warren, Ohio
summary:
WARREN, Ohio (MyValleyTributes) – Wanda E. Kimble, 61, of 2430 Cranwood Drive SW, Warren, departed this life Friday, March 27, 2020 at 6:46 a.m. at Trumbull Memorial Regional Hospital, following a brief illness.
She was born January 5, 1959, in Chicago, Illinois, the daughter of David L. Dotson and Laura Lee Kimble, residing in the area since 1957.

She leaves to mourn one son, Lyndal Lee Kimble of Warren; four brothers, Donnie Dotson of Arlington, Texas, Mark Kimble of Ashtabula, Eric Dotson of Warren and DeAvary Burgess of Columbus; six sisters, Ms. Jacqueline Kimble, Ms. Felicia Sims and Ms. Leslie Burgess, all of Warren, Mrs. Michelle Kimble (Scott) Schaefer of Thornton, Colorado, Ms. Lyn Cheryl Dotson and Ms. Jennifer Dotson, both of Warren; eight grandchildren, nine great-grandchildren and a host of relatives and friends.
She was preceded in death by her parents; one son, Edtwan Kimble and one brother, Darryl Kimble.

title: Battle in Big D: Packers, Cowboys meet on the gridiron at AT&T Stadium on Sunday
summary:
× Battle in Big D: Packers, Cowboys meet on the gridiron at AT&T Stadium on SundayDALLAS — The Green Bay Packers hope to get back to their winning ways when they visit AT&T Stadium in Arlington, Texas to face the Dallas Cowboys on Sunday, Oct. 6.
Both the Packers and Cowboys enter week 5 of the NFL season with 3-1 marks.
According to Packers.com, Green Bay leads the regular-season series with Dallas, 15-13, while the two teams have each won four games against each other in the postseason.
The Packers have won seven of the last eight contests — and including the playoffs, Green Bay is 3-0 against Dallas at AT&T Stadium.
QB Aaron Rodgers has started eight times against the Cowboys (including playoffs), with the Packers winning six of the contests.

title: Prosecutor: Arlington Man Shot and Beheaded Roommate
summary:
A prosecutor says a North Texas man shot and killed then beheaded his roommate and fatally shot the roommate's 17-year-old girlfriend as she tried to flee.
Hector Acosta-Ojeda is charged with capital murder in the September 2017 killings of Erick Zelaya and Iris Chirinos.
The Fort Worth Star-Telegram reports that Tarrant County prosecutor Kevin Rousseau said Acosta-Ojeda shot Zelaya twice in the head while he slept.
Zelaya's severed head was later found on a trail near AT&T Stadium in Arlington.
Rousseau told the jury that Acosta-Ojeda said he killed Zelaya because he recently confessed to shooting at Acosta-Ojeda's former home in Arlington months earlier.

title: Fire breaks out at Globe Life Field, the new Texas Rangers stadium
summary:
A fire broke out Saturday afternoon inside the new Rangers ballpark sending a pillar of black smoke into the sky above the still under construction stadium, scheduled to open next year.
Arlington firefighters are trying to get a handle on a fire at Globe Life Field this afternoon.
It started about 100 feet off the ground under the retractable roof of the new ballpark, Arlington fire officials said.
The Rangers will coordinate a response to the fire with Manhattan Construction Co., said John Blake, the Rangers’ executive vice president of communications.

title: Arlington ISD Wants $966M Bond on Top of Billion-Dollar Debt
authors: Erin Anderson Is The Metroplex Bureau Chief For Texas Scorecard
Government Actions That Impact People In Communities Throughout The Area. A Native Texan
Erin Grew Up In The Houston Area
summary:
Property taxpayers in Arlington Independent School District have taken a beating in the past several years, thanks to the district’s runaway spending and debt.
Arlington ISD trustees unanimously agreed in August to put a $966 million bond proposal on the November ballot—larger than the district’s last two bonds combined.
The district already owes over $1.1 billion in bond debt principal and interest, all of which must be repaid with property taxes.
The average Arlington ISD homeowner’s school property tax bill increased 42 percent over the past five years, from $1,490 to $2,166.
In addition to Arlington’s new school debt proposal, voters across Tarrant County will also decide on an $825 million bond package for the Tarrant County College District.

Chad with his three childrenThe primary goal for most GM workers during the strike was to eliminate the temp job category and secure equal pay and benefits for all workers.

title: Pumpkin Nights at Howell Farms
summary:
Pumpkin Nights is launching an interactive Halloween experience and festival unlike anything else in Dallas/Fort Worth this October.
Plan your own adventure at Howell Farms and get transported into the enchanted world of Pumpkin Nights with dazzling, multi-sensory Halloween displays and seven Pumpkin Lands created with more than 3,000 artistically hand-carved real and synthetic pumpkins.
The outdoor, magical Halloween experience will be rolling into town for 24 days—opening on Thursday, Oct. 10 through Sunday, Nov. 3.
Heroes will start their journey by walking through the Pumpkin Passage, a pumpkin tunnel with 600 hand carved jack-o-lanterns before embarking on their quest to discover seven immersive Pumpkin Lands.

title: Expert: UAW Strike Has Cost GM $1B; Forced Mexican Plant Closure
summary:
The strike has cost GM just over $1 billion thus far, JP Morgan analyst Ryan Brinkman estimated Tuesday in a note to investors.
The plant shutdowns mean that GM has lost any new supplies of its light-duty Chevrolet Silverado, the company’s top-selling U.S. vehicle.
Earlier GM had to close a Mexican engine plant and an assembly plant in Canada due to the strike.
Workers are having to get by on $250 per week in strike pay instead of their normal base pay of about $1,200 per week.
GM’s losses are mounting each week the strike continues, costing about $480 million in the first week and another $575 million in the second, Brinkman wrote.

summary:

title: Picket Lines Continue as GM Workers in Arlington are Set to Vote on Tentative Deal
summary:

The proposed agreement gives longtime workers 2-to-4 percent pay raises over several years, and a ratification bonus of 11-thousand dollars per workers; the bonus has been estimated to cost the automaker some $500M.

title: 1 Dead, 1 Injured in Arlington Shooting
summary:
One person is dead and a second is injured after a shooting in East Arlington Saturday night, police say.
The shooting happened at about 6:34 p.m. Saturday in the 2400 block of Summer Place Drive, according to Arlington police.
One person died at the scene, while the other was taken to Mansfield Methodist Hospital with injuries that were not considered to be life-threatening and later released, police said.
Police said investigators were working to determine if the person taken to the hospital was a direct participant in the incident.
The cause of the shooting was still under investigation Saturday night.

title: Census: Texas Counties Saw Large Population Gains Over Past Decade
summary:
Six of the 10 U.S. counties with the largest population gains this decade were in Texas, according to the U.S. Census Bureau’s July 1, 2019, population estimates released this week.
“One interesting trend we have seen this decade is widespread population decline among smaller counties, while larger counties tended to have population growth,” Christine Hartley, a demographer in the Census Bureau’s Population Division, said.
“Three out of four counties with a population of less than 10,000 in 2010 had even smaller populations in 2019.
At the same time, three out of four counties of 50,000 or more were larger in 2019 compared to 2010.”The pattern among larger counties is particularly evident in the West and South.
Vintage 2019 is the last series of population estimates to be released before the 2020 Decennial Census is completed.

title: Josh Hamilton indicted, accused of injuring his oldest daughter
summary:
Former Texas Rangers slugger and 2010 AL MVP Josh Hamilton was indicted Monday on one count of injury to a child with intentional bodily injury, a third-degree felony, stemming from a Sept. 30 incident in which he was accused of hurting his oldest daughter.
Hamilton was accused of throwing a water bottle at his oldest daughter, 14, and hitting her in the chest, according to an arrest warrant affidavit.
Hamilton also grabbed the chair where his daughter had propped her feet and yanked it from under her, then tossed the chair in her direction, police said.
According to the affidavit, the chair struck her leg.
“The Texas Rangers take the issue of family violence very seriously,” the team said in a statement following Hamilton’s arrest.

The men believed they were chatting online with a minor child between 13 and 16 years old, police said.
"The collaboration between Texas DPS, the Tarrant County Sheriff's Office and Arlington PD demonstrates our commitment to identifying and arresting these individuals who prey on our most vulnerable victims, our children," Arlington Police Chief Will Johnson said.

title: Coronavirus originated in bungled experiments at Wuhan lab, bombshell report claims
summary:
'Patient zero' worked at the Wuhan lab, and spread the virus into the local population after leaving work, sources who had been briefed on intelligence told the outlet.
'What we do know is we know that this virus originated in Wuhan, China,' Pompeo told Fox News on Wednesday evening.
The Wuhan lab is China's only bio-safety level four (BSL-4) facility, and has long been eyed with suspicion as scientists try to determine how the deadly virus crossed over into humans.
After the coronavirus outbreak began, officials at the lab destroyed samples of the virus, erased early reports, and suppressed academic papers, sources told Fox News.
Officials at the Wuhan lab have previously dismissed any allegation that the virus emerged from the facility, calling them baseless conspiracy theories.

title: Arlington Businesses Partner With Boys & Girls Clubs To Fulfill Christmas Wishes
summary:
From the City of Arlington:December 17, 2019Members of the Boys & Girls Clubs of Greater Tarrant County will have their wish lists granted this holiday season, thanks to some local businesses.
More than 20 companies stepped up to provide gifts and much-needed items for the thousands of students served by The Boys & Girls Clubs.
"Our holiday partnerships connect companies in our community to young people who need extra attention and care during this holiday season ," said Daphne Barlow Stigliano, CEO & President of Boys & Girls Clubs of Greater Tarrant County.
The Boys & Girls Clubs of Greater Tarrant County has already hosted one holiday partnership event at an Arlington branch with three more to come.
The Boys & Girls Clubs of Greater Tarrant County serve more than 23,000 children each year with programs focusing on academic success, healthy lifestyles and positive citizenship.

title: Texas Rangers’ game times for 2020 season, inaugural year at Globe Life Field revealed
summary:
Update, noon Wednesday: The opening of Globe Life Field will allow the Rangers to start a number of games earlier, though there isn’t a marked upturn in day games.
There are 23 day games scheduled at Globe Life Field in 2020 compared to 21 in 2019 at Globe Life Park.
While most home games start at 7:05 p.m., the usual Saturday start time will move to 6:05 p.m.
“We think these adjustments will be very convenient for our fans.”There are three exceptions to the Saturday start times, all for a national television window.
After the short delay before the Globe Life Field “official” opener, there will be plenty of early-season home games to satisfy novelty seekers.

title: Arlington's New Christmas Tree Shining Bright For The Holiday Season
summary:
From the City of Arlington:December 3, 2019Arlington's New Christmas Tree Shining Bright For The Holiday SeasonCity and community leaders helped kick off the holiday season in The American Dream City on Monday night by lighting Arlington's new 65-foot artificial Christmas tree.
The Christmas tree, which features assorted styles of traditional red and silver ornaments, thousands of lights, and a 7-foot tall lighted star tree topper, is located near the Levitt Pavilion in Founders Plaza.
It was made possible by the Arlington Tomorrow Foundation and the work of volunteers with the nonprofit organization, Arlington Christmas Parade, Inc., which has organized the popular Arlington Holiday Lights Parade for years.
"The new artificial tree aligns with our City Council's mission to revitalize Downtown and make sure the heart of our city is a place people want to visit.
In keeping with tradition, the official tree lighting ceremony will follow the end of the Arlington Holiday Lights Parade at around 7 p.m. on Dec. 14.

title: Arlington Hosts PY1 Pyramid Combines Lights, Sounds & Visual Effects Outside Globe Life Park
summary:
From the City of Arlington:December 10, 2019Arlington Hosts PY1 Pyramid Combines Lights, Sounds & Visual Effects Outside Globe Life ParkYou may have seen the massive pyramid going up outside Globe Life Park and wondered exactly what it is.
The building is part of the PY1 Experience — combining light, sounds and visual effects.
"Through the Echoes" takes visitors on an emotional journey through space and time using lasers, projections, lightscapes and special effects.
Guests can also enjoy "Stella — The Time Machine Journey."
On Saturday nights and select other days, the Pyramid will transform for "PY1 Nights," which includes a laser show and dance floor for guests 21 years old and up.

title: Arlington Police Officer William Bill Enjoys Christmas Day Off As Chief Works In His Place
summary:
Every year, Arlington Police Chief Will Johnson selects an employee to take off on Christmas, and he works in their place.
This Christmas, Officer William Bill, who has been with the department for 14 years, got to stay home with his wife and kids on the holiday.
When I wake up for Christmas, most people will have their dad there, but duty calls.”Meantime, Chief Johnson spent Christmas patrolling the streets in Bill’s place.
“No matter who you are or what you do or where you live, you can give back,” said Chief Johnson.
“That’s the gift of time, and time with the family,” said Officer Bill.

title: Boy With Half a Heart Warms Hearts for Christmas
summary:
An Arlington boy is setting an example for us all this Christmas: Giving without expecting anything in return.
Elliott Wyche, 4, was diagnosed with Hypoplastic left heart syndrome in April 2015, months before his birth on Aug. 12.
“He essentially is walking around, running around, with only half of a heart,” his mother Ashley Wyche said.
Wyche wanted to donate them to Arlington’s Santa Cop program instead.
“He’s going through so much, but he's giving back to show that not only are we heroes for some kids, but he's my hero!” Arlington officer Carla Strauser said.

title: Arlington Police Sergeant Accused of Assault Family Violence
summary:
An Arlington police sergeant has been arrested, accused of assault family violence.
Arlington police said Frank Vacante, a 12-year veteran of the department currently assigned to the Support Operations Bureau, surrendered at the Tarrant County Jail Monday and was booked on one charge of assault - family violence/impede breath circulation.
After taking the report, Vacante was placed on administrative leave pending the outcome of the criminal and administrative review.
Police officials said Vacante will remain on leave pending the outcome of the internal and criminal investigations.
As of Monday afternoon, Vacante was still listed as an inmate at the Tarrant County Jail, being held on $2,500 bond.

title: Here’s what winter could look like for Dallas-Fort Worth without an El Niño or La Niña
summary:
An outlook issued by the National Weather Service expects conditions to stay neutral in the Pacific Ocean this winter, meaning neither an El Niño nor a La Niña is expected to form.
Temperatures in the area could be warmer than normal, based on a recent trend of warmer winters, according to the weather service.
If you missed it earlier this week, the 2019-20 NOAA #Winter Outlook was issued.
The outlook says excessive rainfall events are less likely, and it calls for near-normal amounts of snowfall and winter weather events.
The last time Dallas-Fort Worth saw significant snowfall was 3.5 inches in March 2015, according to the weather service.

title: Manhunt For North Texas Jewelry Store Burglar Who Has Swiped $50K+ In Goods
summary:
Now detectives are asking for help identifying the burglar who has gotten away with more than $50,000 in fine jewelry.
It started on December 7 when someone tried to break into the Robbins Brothers jewelry store along the Interstate-20 service road in Arlington.
The suspect turned the power off to the business and tried to break the front glass doors, but was unsuccessful.
Police say thousands of dollars in jewelry were taken.
Officials didn’t detail how the suspect got into the jewelry store, but said they believe the same suspect in the Arlington cases committed the crime.

title: Man Killed in Arlington Hit-and-Run, Police Say
summary:
A 29-year-old man is dead after he was struck by a car in Arlington early Friday morning, police say.
Arlington police said they answered a call in the 3500 block of Division Street around 2:30 a.m. Friday and found the man, who was pronounced dead at the scene.
Investigators believe the man was struck by a vehicle that was driving eastbound on Division Street, police said.
The Tarrant County medical examiner identified the man as Jonathan Charles Livermore, 29, of Fort Worth.
Anyone with information about the hit-and-run is was asked to call Arlington police crash investigator Joe Shipp at 817-575-8602.

title: Staff at Arlington Memorial Hospital lines hallway in honor of veteran, Pearl Harbor survivor
summary:
Melvin Ray Cook died on Thursday at the age of 97.
Melvin Ray Cook of Grand Prairie died at the age of 97 of congestive heart failure.
He was a U.S. Army Ranger and Pearl Harbor survivor in World War II.
Staff at Arlington Memorial Hospital lined the hallway as his flag-draped casket was taken from the hospital to a funeral home.
Melvin Ray Cook, U.S. Army Ranger, Pearl Harbor.

title: Baylor recruiting report card: After breakout Big 12 title game performance, Jacob Zeno leads 2019 class full of potential
summary:
With the early signing period approaching, here’s the final of our four-part series looking back at Baylor’s past four recruiting classes.
Best player in the classQuarterback Jacob Zeno: The four-star quarterback was thrown into action in the Big 12 championship against Oklahoma.
Zeno completed two big passes for 159 yards and a touchdown in the fourth quarter to force overtime.
The four-star athlete entered the transfer portal early in his Baylor tenure and announced his transfer to Utah on Nov. 21.
If Zeno eventually become the Bears’ quarterback of the future and others rise into more prominent roles, this grade will take a big leap forward.

summary:

The Holiday Lights Parade is more than just a spectacular parade — it's a full day of fun.
The George W. Hawkes Downtown Library will offer a variety of free activities before the parade including reindeer games, crafts and photos with Santa.
The party runs from 2 p.m. until 5 p.m. Click here to learn more about the 2019 Holiday Lights Parade.

title: Arlington Pastor Brett Monroe Arrested, Charged With Possession Of Child Pornography
summary:
– An Arlington pastor remained jailed Friday after being arrested days earlier and charged with possession of child pornography.
Police arrested Brett Monroe at his home in southwest Arlington on December 11.
According to Monroe’s LinkedIn profile and an older version of a church webpage, he was on staff at Heritage Baptist Church in Arlington.
All references to the 38-year-old on the church webpage have since been removed.
It has been confirmed that Monroe is a volunteer at Corey Academy of Fine Arts & Dual Language in the Arlington Independent School District.

title: Longtime Arlington Police Officer Gets Special Recognition From City Leaders
summary:
From the City of Arlington:December 5, 2019Longtime Arlington Police Officer Gets Special Recognition From City LeadersMention the name PJ Brock to any Arlington Police officer and you're almost guaranteed to get a smile in return.
Though deeply respected for her stellar police work, Brock truly made her mark when APD's chaplain approached her about helping to coordinate officer funerals.
Having given so much of herself to others, this week, the Arlington City Council wanted to give Brock something in return.
During Tuesday night's City Council meeting, Mayor Jeff Williams surprised her by presenting her with a Proclamation declaring Dec. 3, 2019 as "PJ Brock Day" in the City of Arlington.
This press release was produced by the City of Arlington.
